metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Date Formats
JavaScript Date Input
There are generally 3 types of JavaScript date input formats:
content.html: There are generally 3 types of JavaScript date input formats:

content.text: The ISO format follows a strict standard in JavaScript.
content.html: The ISO format follows a strict standard in JavaScript.

content.text: The other formats are not so well defined and might be browser specific.
content.html: The other formats are not so well defined and might be browser specific.

content.text: JavaScript Date Output
Independent of input format, JavaScript will (by default) output dates in full text string format:
content.html: Independent of input format, JavaScript will (by default) output dates in full text string format:

content.code: Sun May 25 2025 17:58:27 GMT+0100 (Western European Summer Time)
content.code_html: Sun May 25 2025 17:58:27 GMT+0100 (Western European Summer Time)

content.text: JavaScript ISO Dates
ISO 8601 is the international standard for the representation of dates and times.
content.html: ISO 8601 is the international standard for the representation of dates and times.

content.text: The ISO 8601 syntax (YYYY-MM-DD) is also the preferred JavaScript date format:
content.html: The ISO 8601 syntax (YYYY-MM-DD) is also the preferred JavaScript date format:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015-03-25");

content.text: The computed date will be relative to your time zone. Depending on your time zone, the result above will vary between March 24 and March 25.
content.html:
The computed date will be relative to your time zone.
Depending on your time zone, the result above will vary between March 24 and March 25.

content.text: ISO Dates (Year and Month)
ISO dates can be written without specifying the day (YYYY-MM):
content.html: ISO dates can be written without specifying the day (YYYY-MM):

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015-03");

content.text: Time zones will vary the result above between February 28 and March 01.
content.html: Time zones will vary the result above between February 28 and March 01.

content.text: ISO Dates (Only Year)
ISO dates can be written without month and day (YYYY):
content.html: ISO dates can be written without month and day (YYYY):

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015");

content.text: Time zones will vary the result above between December 31 2014 and January 01 2015.
content.html: Time zones will vary the result above between December 31 2014 and January 01 2015.

content.text: ISO Dates (Date-Time)
ISO dates can be written with added hours, minutes, and seconds (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ):
content.html: ISO dates can be written with added hours, minutes, and seconds (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ):

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015-03-25T12:00:00Z");

content.text: Date and time is separated with a capital T.
content.html: Date and time is separated with a capital T.

content.text: UTC time is defined with a capital letter Z.
content.html: UTC time is defined with a capital letter Z.

content.text: If you want to modify the time relative to UTC, remove the Z and add +HH:MM or -HH:MM instead:
content.html: If you want to modify the time relative to UTC, remove the Z and add +HH:MM or -HH:MM instead:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015-03-25T12:00:00-06:30");

content.text: UTC (Universal Time Coordinated) is the same as GMT (Greenwich Mean Time).
content.html: UTC (Universal Time Coordinated) is the same as GMT (Greenwich Mean Time).

content.text: Omitting T or Z in a date-time string can give different results in different browsers.
content.html: Omitting T or Z in a date-time string can give different results in different browsers.

content.text: Time Zones
When setting a date, without specifying the time zone, JavaScript will use the browser's time zone.
content.html: When setting a date, without specifying the time zone, JavaScript will use the browser's time zone.

content.text: When getting a date, without specifying the time zone, the result is converted to the browser's time zone.
content.html: When getting a date, without specifying the time zone, the result is converted to the browser's time zone.

content.text: In other words: If a date/time is created in GMT (Greenwich Mean Time), the date/time will be converted to CDT (Central US Daylight Time) if a user browses from central US.
content.html: In other words: If a date/time is created in GMT (Greenwich Mean Time), the date/time will be converted to CDT (Central US Daylight Time) if a user browses from central US.

content.text: JavaScript Short Dates.
Short dates are written with an "MM/DD/YYYY" syntax like this:
content.html: Short dates are written with an "MM/DD/YYYY" syntax like this:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("03/25/2015");

content.text: WARNINGS !

content.code_html: const d = new Date("2015-3-25");
const d = new Date("2015/03/25");
const d = new Date("25-03-2015");

content.text: JavaScript Long Dates.
Long dates are most often written with a "MMM DD YYYY" syntax like this:
content.html: Long dates are most often written with a "MMM DD YYYY" syntax like this:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("Mar 25 2015");

content.text: Month and day can be in any order:
content.html: Month and day can be in any order:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("25 Mar 2015");

content.text: And, month can be written in full (January), or abbreviated (Jan):
content.html: And, month can be written in full (January), or abbreviated (Jan):

content.code_html: const d = new Date("January 25 2015");
const d = new Date("Jan 25 2015");

content.text: Commas are ignored. Names are case insensitive:
content.html: Commas are ignored. Names are case insensitive:

content.code_html: const d = new Date("JANUARY, 25, 2015");

content.text: Date Input - Parsing Dates
If you have a valid date string, you can use the Date.parse() method to convert it to milliseconds.
content.html: If you have a valid date string, you can use the Date.parse() method to convert it to milliseconds.

content.text: Date.parse() returns the number of milliseconds between the date and January 1, 1970:
content.html: Date.parse() returns the number of milliseconds between the date and January 1, 1970:

content.code_html: let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");

content.text: You can then use the number of milliseconds to convert it to a date object:
content.html: You can then use the number of milliseconds to convert it to a date object:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");
const d = new Date(msec);

content.code:
let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");
const d = new Date(msec);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");
const d = new Date(msec);

content.code_html:
let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");
const d = new Date(msec);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let msec = Date.parse("March 21, 2012");
const d = new Date(msec);

content.text: Complete JavaScript Date Reference
For a complete Date reference, go to our:
content.html: For a complete Date reference, go to our:

content.text: Complete JavaScript Date Reference .
content.html: Complete JavaScript Date Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Date properties and methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Date properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What date is created with the following code: const d = new Date('2024'); .
content.html:
What date is created with the following code:
const d = new Date('2024');.

content.question: What date is created with the following code:const d = new Date('2024');.
